"description":"

Our private GP consultation typically involves a one-on-one appointment with a general practitioner (GP) in our clinic. During the consultation
column6: the GP will ask you about your medical history and symptoms
column7: perform a physical examination if necessary
column8: and make a diagnosis or provide treatment options. The GP may also order any necessary *tests or refer the patient to a specialist if needed. In most cases we find we are able to meet our patient\u2019s needs fully. Occasionally
column10:
specialist referral is necessary. This is included in the consultation fee. 


The consultation usually lasts between 20 to 45 minutes (depending on booking choice) 

* ECGs
column11:
lab tests are additional. 


Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our contact us\u202fpage.

"description":"

Regular ECGs are done at rest
column6: and are designed to pick up disturbances of heart rate
column7: rhythm and electrical conduction. They may also show evidence of the effects of high blood pressure
column8:
and other potentially dangerous conditions. 


Regular ECGs are suitable as part of the general assessment for palpitations
column10:
breathlessness at rest or as a pre-operative assessment for over 45s.  


When you have a regular ECG with us
column11: it is a full 12 lead study that is read by an experienced doctor who will give you a report which can be used by any doctor to whom you may subsequently be referred. If abnormalities are found which need attention
column12: a recommendation will usually be made for further evaluation by a cardiologist
column13:
which we can arrange and is included in the consultation fee. 

"

column5:
"description":"

20 minute telephone/video consultation with GP/Nurse. 


Conditions: 

  • telephone consultations are only offered through a booked time slot - limited to 20 minutes 
  • payment is made at the time of booking the consultation 
  • patients will then be offered a time slot that suits them
column6:
to call back and speak to the doctor. 


There are certain situations where the doctor will need to examine you
column7:
if this is the case they will advise during the telephone consultation. Those patients that then decide to use Doctor Today will be offered a consultation at a reduced rate of \u00a385 (normally \u00a3100) 


Prescriptions are issued at the discretion of the doctor. These will be sent directly to the pharmacy. 

"

column4: "sub_service_name":"Ear syringing (includes free follow-up appointment within one week if necessary) "
column5:
"description":"

You may require our ear care consultation service if you are experiencing any of the following: 


1. Ear pain\u202f 

If you have pain in your ear
column6:
you should see a qualified clinician as soon as possible. Pain generally indicates an infection which may benefit from medication. It may also be caused by dental problems. Either way your ear should be checked by a competent clinician. 

 

2. Deafness in one ear without pain 

This is often caused by the accumulation of wax in the ear canal
column7:
particularly if you have inadvertently pushed wax inwards using a finger or a cotton bud. The first step is to soften the wax by putting a few drops of olive oil into the ear while lying down on the opposite side. Wait 10 minutes and then put a small plug of cotton wool loosely in the ear hole opening. Repeat this for three days. 

If you are still having problems
column8: come in and see us so that the ear canal can be inspected for wax
column9: and - if present in significant amounts - we can use our \"Pro-pulse\" ear irrigator to remove the wax safely. If the wax has not been softened with olive oil for three days prior to your visit
column10:
you may be advised to do so and come back again after three days (at no extra charge). 

 

3. Deafness without pain or wax 

If there is no wax or ear infection to account for hearing loss
column11: we advise investigation of this and will refer you to an ear specialist
column12:
which we can arrange for you. 

An ear care consultation costs \u00a3110
column13: which includes costs of infection treatment or ear irrigation (whichever
column14: if any
column15:
is appropriate as discussed above). Follow up appointments within 1 week are free of charge; after one week follow up appointments are charged at \u00a375. 

Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our\u202fcontact us\u202fpage.

"

column7: 0);\">As a private GP practice
column8: we offer occupational health services to support the well-being and productivity of employees in the workplace. These services may include pre-employment assessments
column10: health promotion programs
column11: and injury management. By providing access to these services
column12: the practice can help businesses comply with health and safety regulations
column13: while also promoting a healthy work environment for employees. We can also offer on-site health assessments and consultations to minimize disruption to the employee's work schedule. Offering occupational health services can help to improve employee morale and reduce sick leave
column14:
ultimately leading to a more efficient and productive workforce. 

"

column5:
"description":"

Aesthetics at Doctor Today is offered by our Nurse Prescriber
column6:
Debbie Joffe. 

Feeling happy inside goes hand-in-hand with feeling happy on the outside. Aesthetic procedures such as Wrinkle Reduction Treatments are a great way to help clients love what they see in the mirror each day. 

Patients receive a free aesthetic consultation before any procedure.


BOTOX

Botox
column7: the most recognised and commonly used non-surgical cosmetic therapy
column8: diminishes lines and wrinkles caused by smiling
column9: laughing and frowning. Commonly treated wrinkles are those that occur on the forehead
column10: the Glabella region (otherwise known as the \u201811\u2019 lines that form in between your eyebrows) and \u2018crow\u2019s feet\u2019
column11:
the wrinkles that occur in the outer corners of the eyes. 


How does Botox work?

Botox works by relaxing the contraction of certain facial muscles
column12:
thereby smoothing out the overlying skin.


Is the treatment painful? 

Botox injections involve such tiny needles that the treatment is virtually painless.  


Are there any side effects? 

There may be some temporary redness
column13: tenderness
column14:
swelling and bruising at the injection sites. Serious side effects and allergic-type reactions are extremely rare. 


Prices: 

Botox 1 area: \u00a3190 

Botox 2 area's: \u00a3240 

Botox 3 area's: \u00a3290 

"

Obagi Medical Products have been specifically formulated to transform the skin from within to result in younger
column8: healthier-looking skin. The Obagi Medical Product range helps reduce the visible signs of ageing such as fine-lines

column5:
"description":"

Our wound care clinic is run by Prescribing Nurse Debbie Joffe. 

 Aiming to provide both ongoing care (for chronic wounds) and dress acute wounds
column6:
we have a range of cleansing packs and specialist dressings. 


Wounds that we can dress: 

  • Lacerations/cuts due to trauma 
  • Surgical wounds 
  • Suture/staple removal and dressing 
  • Cosmetic wounds 
  • Burns 
  • Ulcers 
  • Abscesses/cysts: post-drainage procedures 
  • Swelling/bruising (following trauma) 


We will not only review your wound
column7: but we will cleanse it and dress it regularly (if needed). If your wound is beginning to look like it may be infected
column8:
we will also offer suitable treatment or referral if needed.  

We make use of the most appropriate
column9: evidence based dressings for your wound to aid your recovery process
column10:
to minimise scarring and maximise healing.  

Once your injury has been assessed
column11:
the best dressing is selected for your wound to enable the quickest possible tissue recovery. 

You will be given thorough after-care advice. Until your wound is fully healed
column12:
our team can continue to dress and review your wound. 


Woundcare Package prices (all inclusive* ). 

One off wound care dressing/ Suture removal - \u00a350 

5 woundcare dressing appointments: - \u00a3200 

10 wouncare dressing appointments \u2013 \u00a3300 

Personalised packages also available for chronic wounds POA 


Please note that this service is by appointment only. 

*( inclusive of nurse consultation
column13:
wound cleaning and dressing with basic in-stock dressings. More complicated dressings may require additional payment based on cost of complex materials needed)  

"

column5:
"description":"

Our popular fast-track travel clinic at Doctor Today offers you an individually-tailored course of travel vaccinations
column6: anti-malarial medication and travel advice appropriate to your destination(s)
column7:
length of stay and personal medical circumstances. The consultation for this service is free if vaccinations and/or anti-malarial medications to the value of \u00a335 or more are purchased; otherwise an advice fee of up to \u00a335 applies. We are a registered Yellow Fever Centre. 


Consultation 

Book a consultation for your travel vaccinations and medication. 


Steps 

1.Click on the region in the world map containing your destination. This will allow you to consult the relevant section of the NHS Fit for travel website. 

2.Consult our services and prices list to obtain detailed medical and pricing information about individual vaccinations or anti-malarials. 

3.Fill in our online appointment booking form to discuss your specific needs or email us at enquiries@doctortoday.co.uk. 


You should start planning at least 12 weeks ahead of travelling
column8: which gives plenty of time to space your vaccinations for maximum effect and safety. Accelerated regimes can be done in as little as 4 to 6 weeks
column9: and in emergency in even less time
column10:
although this is not ideal. 


Please note that the information provided by the NHS Fit for travel website is for guideline purposes only and may not be comprehensive
column11: current or appropriate to your personal circumstances. At Doctor Today our travel clinic advisers have access to the specialist TRAVAX\u2122 database containing the most comprehensive and up-to-date information regarding health conditions at destinations around the world. They are also trained in identifying your special needs (e.g. vaccinations recommended may vary according to factors such as the length of your stay
column12: your personal vaccination history
column13: potential interactions with other medication you may be taking
column14:
and whether or not you are pregnant). 

"

Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our contact us page.

column5:
"description":"

At Doctor Today we provide a discreet
column6: confidential sexual health (STD) test consultation service. Our sexual health clinicians are sympathetic and non-judgmental and at all times their top priority is to help you
column7:
so you can approach them with confidence. The tests we use are chosen for their accuracy and ability to minimise patient discomfort.


Patients who make use of this service usually fall into one of three groups:

  • Patients who do not have symptoms but have had unsafe sexual contact with one or more partners of unknown status
  • Patients who have symptoms (such as urethral or vaginal discharge
column8:
sores or burning on passing urine after recent sexual contact)
  • Couples who wish to obtain a clean bill of health before embarking on a new relationship or trying for pregnancy


    • If you have symptoms
column9: appropriate tests will be recommended. For most conditions
column10: tests are not compulsory before treatment but you should be aware that all medications may have side effects and to cover all possibilities you may have to take a wide spectrum of medication
column11: some of which may not be necessary. Whether have symptoms or not
column12:
you may wish to undergo a full sexual health screen where the consultation and a comprehensive set of tests are included in one cost-effective package (more information). 


You should also be aware that any test performed may be negative in the very early stages of some diseases (such as HIV) and that a single negative test does not necessarily guarantee disease-free status. Therefore
column13: a second test is recommended six weeks after any high-risk sexual activity (e.g. intercourse with unknown partners). If tests are done on urine or blood
column14: you will be notified that the results are ready as soon as we have received them from the laboratory. Usually this is within 48 hours. HIV results
column15: for example
column16: are usually available on the same day for those with weekday appointments before 2pm
column17: and by 11am the next business day morning for those with appointments between 2pm and 7pm. Certain more complicated tests (e.g. those involving lab cultures) may take longer. As STIs may also affect your partner(s) it may be recommended that they also be screened or treated. The second consultation in which you are given your results is included in the initial price
column18:
but you do have to pay for any further lab tests performed and/or necessary medications which are prescribed. 


Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our contact us page.

"

column4: "sub_service_name":"HIV test (includes mandatory sexual health test consultation)"
column5:
"description":"

What is HIV?

HIV is a viral infection that is transmitted by intimate sexual contact
column6: infected blood
column7: sharing needles or stick injury
column8:
pregnancy and birth.

The clinical signs of HIV infection may not appear until the disease is well advanced
column9: but flu-like symptoms may occur at any time from 1 to 3 months after infection starts; these include enlarged lymph nodes
column10: fever
column11: headache
column12: muscle pains and tiredness. The AIDS syndrome which occurs in up to 50% of carriers may not appear until many years later when the destruction of the immune response leads to progressive inability to fight infections
column13:
wasting and certain cancers. Usually an HIV carrier will remain infective in spite of not having the overt signs of AIDS - you cannot tell if someone is an HIV carrier just by looking at them.

Prevention is the best strategy (safe sex
column14: avoid sharing needles) since there is at present no effective vaccine. For those infected with HIV
column15: cure is problematic. Modern therapy can do much to improve quality of life and to reduce viral load and infectivity
column16: however
column17:
so the sooner the treatment is started the better.


HIV Testing at Doctor Today

The test used at Doctor Today to diagnose HIV infection is called the HIV-DUO. This costs \u00a3100 inclusive of a sexual health consultation and tests for both HIV 1&2 antibodies (formed in reaction to the virus) and the p24 antigen (part of the virus itself) for earlier diagnosis. Results for this test are usually available within one working day (usually on the same day for those with weekday appointments before 2pm
column18: and by 11am the next business day morning for those with appointments between 2pm and 8pm). This test will usually become positive from 4 weeks after the contact which causes infection. For confirmation purposes
column19: a second test at 3 to 6 months is advised if the initial test is negative. If both are negative
column20: you can be very sure (99.99%) you are not infected with the HIV virus (this is of course provided no further contacts occur in the meantime; you are advised to maintain a policy of safe sex during this period). If earlier diagnosis is required
column21: the HIV-1 proviral DNA by PCR test can be done from day 10 to 14 post-contact
column22: but is more expensive; in addition
column23: not only do results take longer (several days)
column24: but the test is also not quite as general as the DUO as it applies only to HIV-1 infections (the normal type). HIV-2 infection is more common in West African countries and if your contact may have been in this area
column25:
you should back up the HIV-1 proviral DNA test with a DUO test at 4 weeks.

If your initial test is positive
column26: we perform further confirmatory tests for you free of charge. This consists of three divergent methodologies to cross-check the positive result
column27: as clearly a firm and accurate diagnosis is of the utmost importance. If a positive result is confirmed
column28:
we are able to advise you appropriately and to refer you to a specialist clinic for further management.


Why we do not use \"instant\" HIV Tests

The directors of Doctor Today have taken the view that so-called \"instant\" HIV testing by the INSTI or other point of care method will not be offered at this time to our patients for the following reasons:

In areas of low HIV prevalence such as UK
column29: 6 out of every 7 positive instant tests are in fact likely to turn out to be negative
column30:
so patients may be given unnecessary anxiety for no good reason.

  • There is also a small but appreciable false negative rate with instant tests (i.e. test shows negative but in fact the patient is positive)
column31:
which could be disastrous for the patient and their partners if the instant test is relied upon.
  • An instant test is not a lot cheaper (at our clinic) than the HIV-DUO test. Any positive test would have to be followed up with by confirmatory testing which is more sensitive
column32:
so the cost of this would have to be extra. In our clinic the confirmatory testing after a positive HIV-DUO test is done free of charge to the patient. This can be very expensive if it is done separately and is something you need to take into account when choosing where to have your test done.
  • The instant test turns positive some time after the HIV-DUO test is positive (i.e. there is a longer \"window period\").
  • There is no p24 antigen testing with the instant tests which is a big advantage of the HIV-DUO test
column33:
the results for which are usually back within one working day.

For all the above reasons we feel the regular HIV-DUO test is still the most appropriate test for our patients
column34:
with the PCR test for those who feel they cannot wait. For further information please see the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV's guidelines on point-of-care HIV testing.


Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our

this also includes a blood test for herpes antibodies as well as a swab for HPV (human papilloma virus). HPV is linked to cervical cancer in women and genital warts in both women and men.

column5: includes sexual health test consultation)"
column6:
"description":"

Cervical cancer is the twelfth most common type of cancer in women in the UK. Around 950 women in the UK die from this cancer every year. However
column7:
the number of cases diagnosed each year has fallen over recent years. This is because cervical cancer can be prevented by regular cervical screening tests.

Doctor Today offer cervical smears to all women who are sexually active and at risk of HPV and cervical cancer. 

The cost includes a consultation with one of our GPs who will take a full gynaecological history. Results are usually available within 3-4 working days. 

Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our

column5: "description":"
column7: 51);\">We have designed a health check for those people who do not have major medical concerns but want to know where they are in terms of their health. This 30 minute health check is brilliant for those people who do not have alot of time to sit through lengthy health assessments
column8: but would like to be aware of any health issues that may creep up. The 30 miniute health check
column9: performed by our nurse or one of our GPs
column10: includes measurements of your height
column11: weight
column12: body mass index
column13: fat percentage and oxygen saturation
column14: as well as your blood pressure and pulse rate. It includes a blood test for kidney and liver function
column15: blood sugar levels
column16: cholesterol levels
column18: calcium levels and a blood cell count. It also includes a resting ECG and we will will calculate your Q risk (predictor of cardiovascular disease). We will compile a short report
column19: including all your measurements and results
column20:
highlighting any problem areas that need further assessment or review. This health check does NOT include a full consultation and we strongly recommend that you follow up any abnormal results with your own GP or one of the GP's at Doctor Today.

"

column5:
"description":"

Our Well Man Health Assessment provides you the opportunity to have a full medical review of all the important areas relating to male well-being. Our package is designed to allow you to direct your assessment and to allow it to be as extensive as you feel is necessary.


We offer a Basic Well Man Health Assessment which covers core health issues
column6: as well as a number of additional options to suit your individual needs. The basic assessment is based around a 40 minute consultation with a doctor
column7:
and includes:

  • A review of your personal medical history.
  • Measurement of your blood pressure
column8: pulse
column10:
height and Body Mass Index.
  • A clinical examination focusing on testicular and (for those over 45) prostatic health. This includes a detailed explanation of how and when testicular examination should be carried out.
  • Blood tests including full blood count
column11: liver function tests
column12: kidney function tests
column13: iron stores
column14: glucose level
column15:
lipid (cholesterol) profile and thyroid functions.
  • A urine sample to tests for the presence of urinary infections
column16:
blood and glucose.
  • A resting ECG
column18:
51);\">The Basic Well Man Health Assessment costs \u00a3350. Optional additions (at extra cost) include:

  • Prostatic profile for men aged over 45 (\u00a330).
  • Choice of two sexual health screens. Profile 1 (\u00a3110) includes tests for Ureaplasma
column21: Gonorrhoea and Syphilis. Profile 2 (\u00a3155) includes all the tests in Profile 1 plus tests for HIV
column23:
Hepatitis C and Herpes.
  • Testicular tumour profile (\u00a385). Testicular tumours are the most common tumours in males between the ages of 20 and 40
column24:
affecting 2 to 10 males per 100000 per year. This profile is a blood test that detects any levels of the tumour markers most commonly associated with testicular malignancies.
  • Testicular ultrasound (by referral).
  • Male pelvic scan for men aged over 40 (by referral). This is an ultrasound scan of the bladder and prostate.

column5:
"description":"

Our Well Woman Health Assessment provides you the opportunity to have a full medical review of all the important areas relating to female well-being. Our package is designed to allow you to direct your assessment and to allow it to be as extensive as you feel is necessary.

We offer a Basic Well Woman Health Assessment which covers core health issues
column6: as well as a number of additional options to suit your individual needs. The basic assessment is based around a 40 minute consultation with a doctor
column7:
and includes:

  • A review of your personal medical history.
  • Measurement of your blood pressure
column8: pulse
column10:
height and Body Mass Index.
  • A clinical examination focusing on breast and pelvic health. This includes a detailed explanation of how and when self breast examination should be carried out.
  • Blood tests including full blood count
column11: liver function tests
column12: kidney function tests
column13: iron stores
column14: glucose level
column15:
lipid (cholesterol) profile and thyroid functions.
  • A urine sample to tests for the presence of urinary infections
column16:
blood and glucose.
  • A cervical smear test done at time of pelvic examination.
  • A resting ECG.

    • The Basic Well Woman Health Assessment costs \u00a3350. Optional additions (at extra cost) for those aged under 40 include:

    • Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) testing on smear test sample (\u00a385). HPV is also known as the \"genital warts virus\" and is linked to cervical cancer.
    • High vaginal swab (\u00a345). This is normally undertaken for the investigation of vaginal discharge.
    • Choice of two sexual health screens. Profile 1 (\u00a3110) includes a high vaginal swab and specific tests for Chlamydia
column17: Herpes Simplex and Syphilis. Profile 2 (\u00a3155) includes all the tests in Profile 1 plus tests for HIV
column18:
Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C.
  • Pelvic ultrasound (we can refer for this)

    • Optional additions for those over 40 years of age include:

    • Ovarian cancer screening (\u00a3205). This includes a pelvic ultrasound and a blood test for CA125
column19:
which is a tumour marker specific to ovarian cancer.
  • A mammogram (by referral). We will refer you to the radiology department of a nearby private hospital where you will have the mammogram which will be reported on by an experienced radiologist. The mammogram is digital and as such you will be able to keep the images on a disc for comparison with future mammograms.
  • Menopausal blood profile (\u00a395). This blood test can identify when you have entered the menopause.
  • Osteoporosis profile (\u00a3260). This consists of a blood test that examines parameters relating to the health and density of bones (\u00a3105)
column20:
as well as referral to a private hospital for Bone Density Scanning (paid directly to the hospital).

Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our

column5:
"description":"

Our extensive medical includes everything which is included in the well person medical assessment and much more including blood tests. The extensive assessment is based on around a 1 and half hour consultation with a GP which includes:

\u2022 A review of your personal medical history.

\u2022 Measurement of your blood pressure
column6: pulse
column7: weight
column8:
height and Body Mass Index.

\u2022 A clinical examination focusing on breast and pelvic health. This includes a detailed explanation of how and when a self breast examination should be carried out.

\u2022 Blood tests including full blood count
column10: kidney function tests

column14: vitamin D
column15:
vitamin B12 folate and glycated haemoglobin.

\u2022 Tumour marker blood tests

\u2022 Prostate profile (male)

\u2022 A urine test which is sent to our laboratory to test for the presence of urinary infections
column16:
blood and glucose.

\u2022 A cervical smear test done at time of pelvic examination.(Female)

\u2022 A resting ECG.

Optional Extras

\u2022 Choice of two sexual health screens. Profile 1 (\u00a3110) includes tests for Ureaplasma
column19: Gonorrhoea and Syphilis. Profile 2 (\u00a3155) includes all the tests in Profile 1 plus tests for HIV
column21:
Hepatitis C and Herpes.

column22:
as well as referral to a private hospital for Bone Density Scanning (paid directly to the hospital).

\u2022 Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) testing on smear test sample (\u00a390). HPV is also known as the \"genital warts virus\" and is linked to cervical cancer. (Female)

\u2022 High vaginal swab (\u00a350). This is normally undertaken for the investigation of vaginal discharge.(Female)

\u2022 Menopausal blood profile (\u00a395). This blood test can identify when you have entered the menopause.(Female)

column5:
"description":"
  • Gardasil
  • Normal course 3 doses


What is HPV?

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is a sexually transmitted disease associated with genital warts as well as a pre-disposition to cancer of the cervix in females.


What is Gardasil?

Gardasil
column6: also known as Silgard
column7: is a recombinant (artificially manufactured) HPV vaccine made by Sanofi-Pasteur and approved for use in the EU. The license approval covers use in children and adolescents aged 9 to 15 years and in adult females aged 16 to 26 years for the prevention of cervical cancer
column8: high-grade cervical or vulvar dysplasias/ precancers as well as external genital warts (condylomata acuminate) caused by HPV types 6
column10: 16 and 18. These are the commonest (but not the only) viruses associated with cancer of the cervix which kills thousands of women in the UK every year. HPV vaccination provides the best protection against HPV infection that is available for persons having unprotected sexual intercourse with a previously infected partner. The results of the infection are not always obvious
column11: so unless the two partners are both virgins or abstinence is complete
column12: vaccination is advised. Vaccinated persons are NOT protected against other forms of sexually transmitted infection and barrier methods such as condoms are still advised for both heterosexual and homosexual intercourse.
column14: 51);\">Note that HPV vaccination does not eliminate the need for regular cervical smear checks as (a) the infection may have been already acquired
column15: and (b) not all viruses causing cancer are covered. Protection against the 4 type of virus lasts for at least 5 years after completing the full course which consists of three doses by intramuscular injection in the upper arm - usually given at 0
column16: 2 and 6 months. Alternative schedules are possible but it is recommended there should be at least 1 month between the first and the second dose
column17: and at least 3 months between the second and the third
column18:
and all doses should be given within one year.


Potential Side Effects

Side effects are very uncommon as this is NOT a live vaccine; they usually consist of no more than some redness and soreness at the site of the injection which lasts a few days. Very occasionally an allergic reaction may follow such as hives or urticaria. However
column19: HPV vaccine should NOT be used in people who may be hypersensitive (allergic) to the active substance or any of the other ingredients; if a patient shows signs of an allergy after a dose of the vaccine
column20: (s)he should not receive further doses of the vaccine. Vaccination should be postponed in patients who are ill with a high fever
column22: as safety in pregnancy has not been fully assessed; however
column23:
vaccination is not contraindicated in breast feeding women. The vaccine may be given with Hep B vaccines but has not been cleared for co-administration with other vaccines.

In patients who are HIV positive or immuno-compromised for other reasons (e.g. taking strong arthritis medications such as methotrexate)
column24: the normal immune reaction may not be sufficient to prevent subsequent infection in spite of a full course. So although immunisation is not contraindicated in such individuals
column25:
it is wise not to assume full protection and repeat courses may be necessary.


Pricing Information

Each Gardasil injection costs \u00a3180 per dose (normal course three doses at 0
column26:
2 and 6 months). A pre-booked complete three-dose course is available at a discounted price of \u00a3499 (see our full price list).


Further Information

For further information about Gardasil
column27:
see the Gardasil patient information leaflet and the Electronic Medicines Compendium entry for Gardasil.

Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our

column5:
"description":"
  • Sanofi

General information about influenza (flu)
column7: 51);\">Influenza (flu) in healthy persons is generally a very unpleasant illness (high fever of more than 38C
column8: shivering
column10: cough
column11: muscle pains). Caused by the influenza virus
column12: it usually is self-limiting and often follows a 9 day pattern (3 days getting worse
column13: 3 days feeling terrible and 3 days getting better). It should not be confused with the common cold (runny nose
column14: sneezing
column15: feeling weak
column16: mild fever less than 38C) (more information).
column18: 51);\">It is possible to improve immunity against the influenza virus by vaccination; antibiotics are generally useless in the early treatment of flu
column19:
though they may be useful if a secondary infection complicates recovery.


Influenza (flu) vaccinations at Doctor Today

The vaccine we use at Doctor Today is Inactivated Influenza Vaccine by Sanofi. Doses are supplied in prefilled (individual dose) syringes.


For your information:

  • The product is made from viruses selected in the current year by the WHO (World Health Organisation) and CDC (Centre for Disease Control) which are grown in chicken eggs and then inactivated to ensure that transmission of the disease is impossible. IF YOU ARE ALLERGIC TO EGGS OR EGG PRODUCTS
column20: THIS VACCINE IS NOT SUITABLE FOR YOU. If you cannot take the vaccine
column21: you may wish to consider other preventative agents (such as amantadine or oseltamivir)
column22:
but generally these medications are active only against influenza A and must be taken daily even when not ill.
  • This is not a live vaccine
column23: so it can be given to pregnant women
column24: children and immune-compromised persons (i.e. those who are suffering from other illnesses) without problem. All persons aged 65 or over
column25:
pregnant women or immune-compromised patients are advised to undergo vaccination.
  • Nearly all adult influenza vaccines contain trace amounts of a preservative to ensure freedom from contamination (more information). Our vaccine does not contain thiomersal. At present we do not have stocks of preservative-free vaccine. Some alternative preservative-free vaccines have had supply and safety problems recently.
  • Side effects of vaccination are generally mild: sometimes a feeling of soreness at the injection site for a few days
column26:
very occasionally a mild fever. Flu vaccination cannot give you 'flu!
  • Once given
column27: immunity takes approximately two weeks to be sufficient to give good protection. It is important to realise that influenza vaccination does NOT prevent infection by the common cold; nor does it guarantee protection against all known strains of influenza. However
column28: if you are immunised against influenza
column29: and particularly if this is a yearly routine for you
column30: if you do contract influenza of another sort (eg avian/bird flu
column31:
or a new influenza A) then it is believed you are less likely to suffer the severe symptoms which might occur if you get a dose of bird flu while you are low with ordinary flu.
  • There is no specific vaccine available in the UK for avian/bird flu at present. However
column32:
the WHO recommends influenza vaccination for persons at high risk of contracting this disease (more information).
  • Flu vaccination ideally needs to be done once a year every year as the virus continually changes its structure. As you build up immunity to more and more strains
column33:
the chances of getting a recurrent strain become reduced.
  • IF A CHILD UNDER THE AGE OF 12 YEARS HAS NOT PREVIOUSLY BEEN VACCINATED AGAINST FLU
column34:
A REPEAT DOSE IN 4 TO 6 WEEKS IS RECOMMENDED.


General advice on avoiding infection with influenza and common cold viruses

  • These viruses are sometimes transmitted through the air
column35: which of course is difficult to avoid in confined spaces such as underground trains and buses. However a major method of transmission is by rubbing the nose or rubbing the eyes with hands that have touched something that has the virus on it. When a sufferer uses a tissue
column36: the virus is automatically transferred to the hands that hold the tissue. Then the hand touches a stair rail
column37: door handle or any other item around
column38: and others touch the same handle
column39:
rub their nose or eyes and a new infection results. This is why children's nurseries are a very common place to pick up infection.
  • THEREFORE THE MOST IMPORTANT FACTOR IN NOT GETTING INFECTED IS HAND HYGIENE AND MAKING SURE YOU NEVER TOUCH YOUR NOSE OR EYES WITH UNWASHED HANDS
  • Similarly if you have a cold and are sneezing or using toilet tissues
column40: make sure these do not get damp
column41:
and wash your hands frequently. A good tip is to use an alcohol gel to rub on your hands after using tissues if you cannot get to a wash basin.
  • Attention to your general health and improving resistance with a good exercise
column42:
fresh air and healthy eating programme is helpful. Supplementation with zinc 15mg per day is thought to decrease the length of symptoms in recovery from the common cold.

Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our

column5:
"description":"
  • Pneumovax
  • 23-valent pneumococcal vaccination


Pneumococcal vaccinations boost immunity against the pneumococcus bacteria (streptococcus pneumoniae) which is responsible for a good proportion of pneumonia in adults and also for some meningitis and septic joint diseases in adults and children. Normally healthy subjects have good immunity to infection
column6: but if resistance is lowered for any reason (prolonged stress
column7: exposure to cold
column8: age over 65 years
column9:
spleen removal or other illnesses affecting the immune system) infection may strike with devastating consequences - there is a 10% death rate in those who contract an infection if they are over 65 years old.


All persons over 65 years old should be vaccinated
column10: and for this group this should be available free of charge through the NHS. It is often given at the same time as the flu jab
column11: but can be also given at any other time if desired. Others we would recommend having the vaccine are those with chronic heart or lung disease
column12: liver disease
column13: alcoholism
column14: spleen removal or diabetes mellitus. A single vaccination is all that is necessary
column15: and immunity usually lasts a lifetime. It should NOT be repeated within 3 years as a marked reaction may follow
column16: but in spleen removal patients it may be boosted at 5 years. We use the 23-valent vaccine (active immunity is developed against 23 varieties of the infective agent) for all persons over 2 years of age. In many overseas countries
column17: vaccination is also offered to children and if this is the case
column18:
the 7-valent vaccine is recommended for children under the age of 2 years.


Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our

column5:
"description":"
  • Varilrix(GSK) / Varivax (Sanofi)
  • 2 doses for children from 1 year
  • 2 doses for adults


Chickenpox (varicella zoster) is normally a mild disease in younger children but deaths and serious complications can occur in a few children (more information). A recent research report has recommended vaccination as the only way to avoid childhood deaths from chickenpox (more information). The government is still debating as to whether a chickenpox jab can be added to the MMR vaccine
column6: but in view of unfounded concerns about the MMR
column7: initially it will only be offered to teenage children who have not had chickenpox. Parents who wish their children to be vaccinated can do so at our clinic
column8:
but please check the manufacturer's patient information sheet before making your decision.


Adults and teenagers who have not had chickenpox are strongly advised to get vaccinated
column10: as adult chickenpox can be a very nasty disease. Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. column5:
"description":"
  • Rotarix
  • Normal course 2 doses

Rotavirus and the Rotarix vaccine
column7: 51);\">Each year more than 600
column8: 000 children worldwide die from diarrhoeal disease caused by rotavirus
column9: and another two million are hospitalised. Most deaths occur in developing countries where access to treatment is limited; however
column10: nearly every child in the world will suffer an episode of diarrhoea caused by rotavirus before age five. The reason is that
column11: unlike other diarrhoeal diseases
column12: rotavirus is not spread by contaminated water
column13: so simple hygiene measures do not protect children. The rotavirus vaccine (Rotarix
column14: manufactured by GlaxoSmithKline) is the only known way to protect children against the virus at present
column15:
offering a protection level of 85% for all Rotavirus disease and 100% for severe Rotavirus disease (more information).


Optimal vaccination schedule
column17: 51);\">The optimal time to vaccinate a child with Rotarix is at 2 and 4 months when side effects have been shown to be no different to a placebo (sugar water) (more information). If the course is started after 5 months there is a very small increased risk (one in 12
column18: 000 using an earlier vaccine called Rotashield) of intussusception (a condition in which the bowel folds in on itself and may need hospital treatment). If you are considering protection for a child older than 4 months who has not had any diarrhoeal illness since birth because you are travelling abroad where medical resources are poor
column19:
you should discuss the risks with a clinician but generally this is not encouraged by the Department of Health in UK as the vaccine is not yet registered for this group.


Compatibility with other vaccines
column21:
51);\">Oral rotavirus vaccine can be given at the same time as the standard 5-in-1 diphtheria-tetanus-polio-Haemophilus influenzae type b and oral polio vaccine.


Further information
column23: 51);\">Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any further questions or wish to make an appointment. For information on how to get in touch see our

column5:
"description":"


In January 2013
column6: the first ever wide-ranging MenB (meningococcal B meningitis and septicaemia) vaccine was licensed by the European Commission
column7: which judged that the vaccine
column8:
called Bexsero\u00ae was safe and effective. Licensure meant that the vaccine was authorised for use and governments could choose to implement it. 


Why vaccinate? 

For decades
column9: MenB has been the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in the UK and Ireland. Vaccines are the only way to prevent meningitis and have almost eliminated some other kinds of meningitis. Since the first meningitis vaccine was introduced against Hib meningitis in 1992
column10: many kinds of meningitis have been reduced or have dwindled to a mere handful of cases
column11: including Hib
column12: MenC and pneumococcal. Thanks to meningitis vaccines
column13:
thousands of children are alive today who would otherwise have died from these deadly diseases. 

Developing a MenB vaccine has been much more difficult \u2013 until now
column14: protection against MenB has been a distant possibility. Meanwhile
column15:
meningococcal meningitis and septicaemia remain the leading infectious cause of death for children under five in the UK. 

Doses:

More than one dose of the vaccine is needed for sufficient protection \u2013 the total number depends on the age of the person being vaccinated: 

  • Children between 2-6 months of age need 4 doses. 
  • Children between 6 months and 2 years of age need 3 doses. 
  • Children over 2 and adults require 2 doses
column16: but it has not yet been established whether a booster dose is needed to maintain protection in these age groups.
column18:
51);\">The vaccine is not licensed for children under 8 weeks old because there is not enough information about how well the vaccine works in this age group. 

Side effects: 

As with all drugs
column19: vaccines can cause side effects. Vaccine side effects may include soreness/redness/swelling or hardness of skin at the injection site
column24:
sleepiness and rashes. 

Active ingredients in the vaccine: 

The active ingredients that equip our immune system to fight MenB bacteria include four main components of meningococcal bacteria. 

Three of them are proteins found on the surface of the bacteria: 

Factor H Binding Protein (fHbp) 

Neisseria Heparin Binding Antigen (NHBA) 

Neisserial Adhesin A (NadA) 

These three components help meningococcal bacteria invade and survive within the human body. In vaccinated people
column25: the immune system can recognise and \u2018neutralise\u2019 these components
column26:
so the bacteria cannot make them ill. 

The final ingredient is the New Zealand MenB Vaccine (MenZB) derived from the New Zealand outbreak strain of MenB (strain NZ 98/254). 

All of these components have been processed and inactivated and are not part of any living bacteria
column27:
but can still stimulate the immune system.

"
